title: Ten years ago, X was half of Y’s age. If the ratio of their present ages is 3:4, what will be the total of their present ages? - Quora

response.answer_text: The ratio of the present ages is 3:4 Taking 'm’ as the common rational between their ages, let the present age of x be 3m years and the present age of y be 4m years. 10 years ago, x's age would have been 3m–10 and Y’s age would have been 4m-10 years. 10 years ago, x was half of y’s age. So, (3m–10)=1/2 (4m–10) 2(3m-10)=4m-10 6m-20=4m-10 2m=10 m=5 Thus, the present age of x is 3×5 = 15 years and that of y is 4×5= 20 years. The sum of their present ages is 15+20=35 years.

Let, 10 yrs.ago Y was “m” yrs. So, X was “2m” yrs. !0 yrs. later Y is (m+10) yrs and X is ( 2m+10) yrs. [Present ages]. According to condition, (m+10) / (2m + 10) = 3/4 by solving, m= 5 yrs. present ages of X and Y are 15 and 20 yrs. respectively and the total is 35 yrs.
X-10=1/2(y-10) or 2x-20=y-10 or y =2x-10 now x:y=3:4 or x/(2x-10)=3/4 or 4x=6x-30 or 2x=30 or x=15 and y=20. So total of their present ages is 15+20=35 years.
